I haven't played the training levels or DLC, but all boss fights were perfectly balanced on normal mode for me, if you didn't spot a pattern or weakness early enough. You will die though.
I do love Eastern European games as they always seem to offer something unique to their western counter parts, they are less copy and paste.
However, they normally come with some jank and odd non-game breaking quirks.
The main criticism with the game, which is probably a sign of things to come. Is the use of AI assets in the game.

Spectacular. A game that flatters its influences, many as they are. It is an immersive sim leaning towards Bioshock - so much so that I would call this Soviet Shock. There is a little stealth, but gameplay is more about large level traversal and combat with guns, melee and powers. The middle act is a much maligned open world section, which is in actuality a very large funnel-shaped level with optional Portal-esque puzzle dungeons on the way. Bosses were exciting and incredibly animated, though there was one particular boss that was reused a few more times than I would have preferred.

The story was gripping. The world is pro-communist in the way that Prey could be considered pro-capitalist, and the main character sets out into this world as the attack dog of the most powerful man at the top of this alternate history. You should not like this character from the start, and - without spoilers - I'd say not to take anything that is presented at face value. It's very rare to see a character arc in a video game - especially in a protagonist - and I really liked watching P-3's gradual epiphany unfold. It's hard to imagine him not being affected - this world is horrifying, both implicitly and explicitly. 

The artistic direction is without equal, and the experience is topped off with an excellent score.

I do think something needs to be done about the rapid infinite respawns in the overworld/main game land however. Perhaps a way to "hack" each sectors hawk to see you as a friendly or a way to destroy/disable the infinite repair drone spawners. However, the sub dungeons are very well done with varied arenas and exciting bossfights. Many places you can even use objects to take down your enemies which always feels nice in a game interacting with the environment to set off traps for opponents. 

Plot is heavily inspired by games like bioshock and deus ex. So if youve played those games youll know where its going and wont be surprised by potential twists and developments. But its done well enough overall and its hardly a bad thing to find inspiration from those classic titles.

After finishing the game and three of the four DLCs, I can say that this game is pretty damn good. It IS an unabashed ripoff of Bioshock, but instead of exploring Ayn Randian objectivism it is explores (with massive dose of humor and straight-up goofiness) the predominant Soviet ideology of 1955. It asks the question of what the Soviet Union would do with the power it wielded upon the discovery of a basically magical element known as "neuropolymer," which allows it to develop advanced weaponry, robotics, and for lack of a better term, "plasmids." And the result is, as you might expect, disastrous. 

Some people have given this game a lot of guff because it's by a Russian studio and claim that it glorifies the soviet union. Well, frankly, it certainly does not. No more than Bioshock glorified Ayn Randian free marketism. It's a fun, pulpy sci-fi story with some memorable characters and really stunningly original enemy design. 

The gameplay however is not so unique. It is Soviet Bioshock after all (and it lacks the immersive sim DNA of that game, though not its ambition), but the gameplay was never why I kept playing. The gameplay was serviceable enough but the story kept me invested. The ending of the main game had me scratching my head, and not really in a good way, but the DLCs have amended this and I'm excited to see how they conclude this story.

One aspect of the game I really enjoyed is the same mechanic I saw many reviewers shitting on it: the way it handles a sandbox. It is does not merely let you clear areas, nor does it arbitrarily respawn enemies. Instead it is built into an interesting system of repair drones connected to a satellite which can be hacked to shut down all robots in its vicinity for a short time. If you're caught on a security cam fighting a robot, reinforcements arrive and you're in for it. But I found I only ended up in a frustrating situation if I wasn't smart about it, and I thought this was a really novel way to handle a semi-open world. 

There is a lot to explore, and my favorite stuff was running around finding all the Testing grounds to complete my collection of weapon upgrades. The portal-esque puzzles in these levels were challenging at times, but mostly just a fun change of pace from the combat-centric core game. 

At its core, this game is a real spectacle. It's like watching a Red Army parade in Moscow after WW2, but with crazy sci-fi robots, mutants, and fantastical flying machines. The dialogues with dead people who know they're dead but have to wait until their polymer powered device stopped keeping their thoughts alive, the sex-crazed upgrade machine, the sarcastic AI built into your glove, the female service robot who insists you find her best friend whose limbs have been scattered across an entire facility, the talking dolphins, the visual whiplash of Limbo, and the epic boss battles all make this game something unique and fun enough to want to see everything. I can say without doubt, I quite LIKED this game. It is a bit janky, a bit contrived, and quirky as fuck, but it's interesting (especially if you find the Soviet Union a fascinating setting like I do). I put almost 80 hours into a single playthrough and that says a lot.

BIG DISCLAIMER: If you can stand playing a game with subtitles, for the love of god play the game in Russian. I saw some footage of the English voice acting and saw immediately why people thought it was stupid and the main character was annoying. In Russian, he's dumb in an endearing way, like an Arnold Schwarzenegger character. It helps that I speak a bit of Russian and this was some extra credit on my language studies (though the etymology behind "crispy critters" [yebuchi peregiy] remains an enigma to me.) The Russian voice acting plays it more straight, and immerses you in the world so much more.

Game received for $1 from Humble Bundle choice.

Russian power trip fantasy simulator where your glove is smarter than you and does everything better than you (well, do they do that left handed in russia)?

About story:
As this is Russia, research facility robots go haywire and kill people. Player to rescue as he is supa-dupa military guy. Though he gets bonked and starts only with axe and ultra-high tech glove. Player protagonist talks to his hand mostly and his glove trash-talks back. Some reviewers said conversations are infantile but actually most of them are quite good. Though protagonist goes to rage rants for no reason a bit too often but he's mass ax murderer which slops heads off from corpses as he sees fit. This could also be "lost in translation"-type of problem though english in the game is... fairly good. I need to shoot better, okay?

Environment is kind of believable as the world characters live in. Though peasants continue to be peasants and russian (research) villages look totally backwards russian villages even robotic labor is widely available. Game plays around with cold war-era propaganda stories as Dollar-NATO is always making war and always threating hard-working peasant serf. You could only wonder what kind war machines has to be on that side as russians have superb Polymer which is goo-ish solution to everything and Soviet Union is still sort of contained in global scale.

Game also features Mary Sue-style granny right at the start and certain other magical plot devices are just slapped on to get story to go forward. Character actions aren't the most believable but this is FPS game after all. At least player character does not let anyone to push him verbally around but hoo boy he is dumb as sack of bricks without his glove which in turn pushes him then around.

Interestingly, most of actual gameplay, boss events and combat situations are designed in a way that you can expect and prepare for them. So you usually have opportunity to at least save and probably gear-up for the encounter. Save points are mostly abundant which is a good thing as you cannot save everywhere. Backtracking to save points aren't usually blocked.

Playthrough on hardest, after few early enemies which you have to ax with default level ax which is tiresome to Max, game then goes to be super easy. Loot is abundant and as your character "develops" (read: you click on skill tab), game starts to be more and more MOUSE1-fest.

Difficulty spikes on bosses which have funky Elden Ring-style mechanics meaning random spam attacks and large AoE splash areas. Well, probably they cannot damage player otherwise but spamming large AoE is really tiresome. Other enemies have irritating spawn mechanics which could be countered by killing them under some kind of roof. Default mobs aren't much of hazard later on and you'll manage to deal with most of them with your Palpatine lightning and pew-pew electro pistol.

In addition of few normal weapons game has several melee's to offer but actually in addition of Steam achievement, you really do not want to use than just one melee and few select guns. Also player has two magic glove skills to boost player even further which on max level gives you enough edge to deal with anything as MOUSE1 fodder.

There are some real janky moments which are probably just russian design or plainly by-passing game testing but nothing really serious. Testing ground 11 frozen boiler is broken as it probably relies on janky Unreal Engine behaviour on peasant game consoles but you can actually use second boiler twice. I actually have maxxed settings on NV2080 and over 60FPS natively on 2560x1440 (motion blur, DLSS etc. off), so at least this game is min-maxed on polygon level to give decent performance for target audience on serf consoles.

UI at least acknowledges the mouse and I can rebind keys to mouse too but I guess that might be just UE default behaviour. Switching weapon slot places is one of the most confusing but working UI design pieces ever.

Game has Quick Time Events but I CAN DISABLE AND WIN THEM AUTOMATICALLY FROM MENU. Which is total win as I just hate QTE crap though this game seems to have at least same button every time. You absolutely want to turn QTE off as it is insta-death in boss battles.

Map design is a notch of more interesting than your run-of-the-mill console MOUSE1-fest featuring 60's futu-fantasy setting. Game is "open-map" but not open world style. Map (singular) is somewhat spacious but totally free roaming is not possible.

Soundtrack includes both new and oldies goldies style music including Alla Pugacheva whose songs has also spin-offs in finnish. Game though does not have portable radio so you have to use your Ladas with mono radios to create surround sound system. Song list is a bit too small but maybe that's why player cannot listen them except near radios.

Also game features probably real cartoons with wolf and bunny. Usually that is interesting distraction as player just keeps staring inside the game something which is not a game where wolf chases a game (glove makes a joke about that at some point). Also game mimicks or just tries to spin humour from Fallout by having young party-obedient pioneer scout adventuring (similar to Vault Boy) and his nemesis Evil Capitalist Pig. Game does not actually use that design enough so it is more likely nod to Fallout and therefore kind of falls flat.

Warning: game includes Denuvo. You cannot even remove intro videos.

Well, time for conclusion. As game was $1 I could recommend this but definitely would not pay full price.

Final verdict: Would buy Tereshkova seks bot model as soon as they become available in 3-orifice configuration. I am such a filthy Capitalist Pig. Nora was right about everything after all.

I did not enjoy the two hours I played of Atomic Heart. I found the main character unlikeable; he was rude and unpleasant to everyone he interacted with, and I did not find his quips entertaining. The world, while interesting, was introduced through far too much cutscene, and not enough experience as a player. Of the two hours spent, almost half of it was locked into uninteractable cutscenes, or 'walking cutscenes' where I directed my character forward with no additional content beyond pausing occasionally to listen to two or three lines of dialogue shared between NPCs. There was an attempt to show instead of telling, with the most egregious example of 'telling' being a series of informative history posts on a series of signs, while the "current day" state of the world was presented through people acting as people, but the switch from 'normal' to 'incredible violence' was somewhat underwhelming. I think part of the issue was that there was over an hour of setting build-up, and then 'suddenly robots attacked!' It was a radical tone-shift that should have re-engaged me with the story, finally let me engage in gameplay with consequences beyond pressing forward on my joystick...

..,but I didn't find the combat terribly engaging, either. The chunk I experienced was fairly standard gameplay; I picked up a gun, I shot enemies. I could switch to a melee weapon, and hit the enemies. I was introduced to looting the environmental objects, and then immediately taught to use the 'auto-loot all when I press the button' function, so that the looting doesn't actually feel like anything more than poking highlighted background objects to have a random amount of money/health/etc. fall out. I reached the first mini-boss, and it was another generic enemy, but faster and with a ranged attack.

At that point, I was actively displeased with the main character, vaguely interested in the main story, but not really engaged with the gameplay. Perhaps if I got further in, things would change, but based off of my experience with the game, I cannot recommend it, as my opinion is that the interesting worldbuilding was undercut by the uninspired combat and actual RPG elements and actively poisoned by being irritated every time the main character opened his mouth to insult, sass, or sarcastically respond to everyone interacting with him, including the AI(?) inside his own body.

I do want to be a bit clearer with my grievances, since the fact that the developer responded  shows that they're paying attention. I don't mean to be overly harsh in my critique, but I do admit that I was very frustrated with how close Atomic Heart came to being good and yet fell short of delivering every single time it neared brilliance. I'll boil it down into three main problems:

1. [b]Melee is completely superfluous.[/b] The primary function of melee in a game like this is to conserve ammunition: a risk vs reward situation where you have to risk melee combat for the reward of defeating an enemy without spending resources. And it's obvious that you wanted the player to engage in some level of melee, given that you gave the player five different melee weapons to play with, but all of that goes out the window the instant that [spoiler]the player gets the infinite ammo lightning gun[/spoiler]. Now the cost of defeating enemies without spending resources is simply patience, which trivializes the game even on the hardest difficulty.


2. [b]The narrative's immersion and presentation clash with each other constantly.[/b] Atomic Heart goes out of its way to ask the player to participate in certain scenes, but also frequently forces the player to simply witness events. Why am I given dialogue options if they don't matter? Why are some scenes done in the style of Half-Life where I retain control and can interact with the environment, but others are done in a more traditional style where input is taken away as specific events happen? It feels like there's no commitment to one method of storytelling, which makes the story feel inconsistent and makes it difficult to connect to the player character. 

[spoiler]It was especially frustrating to be repeatedly told that the protagonist is being manipulated and the only meaningful choice you're given in the entire game is to either stop letting that happen (which gives you a joke ending that's literally a slideshow) or just go with it (which leads to your character begging for a peaceful dialogue that's withheld for no reason, causing a bad ending after a series of twists that had zero foreshadowing).[/spoiler]


3. [b]Arguably the most important plot point is resolved badly and with no warning.[/b] [spoiler]There is no scene where the player obtains the rings. You just suddenly [i]have[/i] them after an elevator ride, and the only reason I know that is because Charles started telling me about them. No explanation, no reason, no nothing - they're just in your pocket. I looked around, frantically searching the internet to see if I had just managed to bug the game or miss a scene or something, but no: that's apparently the same experience everyone else has had. By all indications, that is the story that Atomic Heart meant to tell.

And then you just toss 'em. Hell, you don't just toss 'em, you toss 'em in the shallows of a beach where all it would take to find them is an afternoon and a can-do attitude. Less than that if you happen to have a metal detector, or are some kind of hyper-intelligent gestalt entity that can shift into any form it pleases.[/spoiler]
